=====2 February =====
=====2 February =====
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
â
During the night of 1–2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria where shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 2 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many protesters from the previous day had remained in Tahrir Square overnight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
+
During the night of 1–2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria where shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 2 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many protesters from the previous day had remained in Tahrir Square overnight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In the morning, internet access had been partially restored and the night-time curfew was eased, running from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/02/egypt-returns-to-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Returns To The Internet - Renesys Blog |publisher=Renesys.com |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref>
In the morning, internet access had been partially restored and the night-time curfew was eased, running from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/02/egypt-returns-to-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Returns To The Internet - Renesys Blog |publisher=Renesys.com |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref>
â
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=Egypt Unrest |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> By midday, the army was asking protesters to go home in order to stabilise the situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/ |title=Goodspeed Analysis: Only the Egyptian Army Has Power To Restore Stability|work=[[National Post]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> State-television then announced: "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
+
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=Egypt Unrest |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb"/> By midday, the army was asking protesters to go home in order to stabilise the situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/ |title=Goodspeed Analysis: Only the Egyptian Army Has Power To Restore Stability|work=[[National Post]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> State-television then announced: "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb"/>
â
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters – The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs came riding on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak Supporters, Protesters Clash in Egypt|author=|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarak's Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> including Tahrir Square<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & Horses Storm into Tahrir Square as Protesters Clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> in what was later known as the (''Battle of Jamal'' or ''Battle of the Camel'')<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12369422|title=Egyptian media: State misinformation amid the protests?|work=[[BBC News]]|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ}}).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=384976|title=Ø¨ÙØ§ÙØ§ (ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ) ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù Ø§ÙØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯|work=Shorouk News|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> Security officials were witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators? |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
+
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters – The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs came riding on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak Backers, Opponents Clash|work=[[Yahoo! News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> some landing on the grounds of the Egyptian Museum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> ''CNN'' interviewed a few anaylsts who suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" has been tried-and-tested at numerous times in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting it could be the same this time despite Interior Ministry denials.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak Backers, Opponents Clash|work=[[Yahoo! News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> some landing on the grounds of the Egyptian Museum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> ''CNN'' interviewed a few anaylsts who suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" has been tried-and-tested at numerous times in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting it could be the same this time despite Interior Ministry denials.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 240: Line 240:
while EU foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton also said that the violence must stop and that Mubarak needs to be more explicit in showing the people what changes would happen.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
while EU foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton also said that the violence must stop and that Mubarak needs to be more explicit in showing the people what changes would happen.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
â
UK Prime Minister David Cameron and the White House condemned the violence, and the US State Department also called for restraint amidst the violence.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> US President Obama also said that a transition must begin "right now."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/02/egypt-army-statement-idUSWEA517720110202 |title=Army Asks Egyptians To Return to Normal Life-TV |work=[[Reuters]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle and French President Nicolas Sarkozy asserted the right to march peacefully, while Turkish Premier Recep Tayyip Erdogan called for an enhanced to democratisations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed concern over a new government saying: "I am convinced that the forces that want to bring change and democratization in Egypt will also enhance peace between Israel and the Arab world. But we are not there yet. The struggle has not been decided...We need to do everything to make sure that peace endures."<ref>{{cite web|author=Alan Silverleib |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/02/egypt.world.reaction/ |title=World Leaders Denounce Attacks on Egyptian Protesters |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
+
UK Prime Minister David Cameron and the White House condemned the violence, and the US State Department also called for restraint amidst the violence.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb"/> US President Obama also said that a transition must begin "right now."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/02/egypt-army-statement-idUSWEA517720110202 |title=Army Asks Egyptians To Return to Normal Life-TV |work=[[Reuters]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle and French President Nicolas Sarkozy asserted the right to march peacefully, while Turkish Premier Recep Tayyip Erdogan called for an enhanced to democratisations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed concern over a new government saying: "I am convinced that the forces that want to bring change and democratization in Egypt will also enhance peace between Israel and the Arab world. But we are not there yet. The struggle has not been decided...We need to do everything to make sure that peace endures."<ref>{{cite web|author=Alan Silverleib |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/02/egypt.world.reaction/ |title=World Leaders Denounce Attacks on Egyptian Protesters |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
{{External media
{{External media
Line 251: Line 251:
Mubarak rejects international calls to step aside. Finance Minister Samir Radwan said the government would be "open to discussion with all shades of political opinions". The army had earlier broadcast a message on television: ''...You began by going out to express your demands and you are the ones capable of restoring normal life.''
Mubarak rejects international calls to step aside. Finance Minister Samir Radwan said the government would be "open to discussion with all shades of political opinions". The army had earlier broadcast a message on television: ''...You began by going out to express your demands and you are the ones capable of restoring normal life.''
â
[[Ali Gomaa]], the [[Grand Mufti]] of Egypt, says: "I greet President Mubarak who offered dialogue and responded to the demands of the people. Going against legitimacy is [[Haram|forbidding]]. This is an invitation for chaos. We support stability. What we have now is a blind chaos leading to a civil war. I call on all parents to ask their children to stay home." A former general who was a part of the intelligence services said that Mubarak would have no qualms about "setting the whole country on fire."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
+
[[Ali Gomaa]], the [[Grand Mufti]] of Egypt, says: "I greet President Mubarak who offered dialogue and responded to the demands of the people. Going against legitimacy is [[Haram|forbidding]]. This is an invitation for chaos. We support stability. What we have now is a blind chaos leading to a civil war. I call on all parents to ask their children to stay home." A former general who was a part of the intelligence services said that Mubarak would have no qualms about "setting the whole country on fire."<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb"/>
â
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day."<ref>{{cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak Must Go by Friday, Says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=[[The Australian]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs ... there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's Revolution Turns Ugly as Mubarak Fights Back|work=[[The Guardian]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Issacharoff |first=Avi |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934 |title=Is Mubarak at the End of His Tether?|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
+
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb"/> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day."<ref>{{cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak Must Go by Friday, Says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=[[The Australian]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs ... there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's Revolution Turns Ugly as Mubarak Fights Back|work=[[The Guardian]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Issacharoff |first=Avi |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934 |title=Is Mubarak at the End of His Tether?|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
